Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part 20, Night of the Heaven of YÄma, Part 7
At that time, the gods proceeded up the mountain peak to the first spotless mirror-like ground.
In the mirror of karmic ground, the gods saw their own bodies clearly and distinctly.
If the gods had previously cultivated body, speech, and mind, in the mirror of karmic ground they would see their own foreheads, where the results of karma and birth and death were manifested.

Just as at a certain time, in a certain place, in a certain country, for certain causes and conditions, with certain signs of decline, and so forth, they would see everything. They would also see the signs of others' impending decline.

Whatever signs of other karmic actions were written in the forehead of the gods, whether signs of rebirth or other karmic actions, all those signs they would see in the mirror of karmic ground, and they would decline from the Heaven of YÄma.

If it is another kind of karma, whether karma of birth, or evil bodily, verbal, or mental karma, due to such causes and conditions, after falling back, one will be born in such-and-such a hell, among such-and-such hungry ghosts, or among such-and-such animals;
having escaped from the realm of animals, due to being deceived by desire and indulgence, and blown by the wind of karma, one will be reborn in such-and-such a place.

Moreover, in this way, desire appears in the middle of the day. In the letters and drawings on the forehead, one sees everything completely.ğŸ”½In the drawings on the forehead, one also sees desire appearing in the middle of the day in this way, and the corresponding antidotes to such desires, namely, cultivating the view of desire as being without light, so as not to be deceived by those desires.

Moreover, those desires have different antidotes, namely, seeing that this form is a false view. Having seen in accordance with such form, the mind correctly contemplates, and the mind of longing does not increase further.
In the same way, as the faults of the five sense objects are seen, the gods will no longer take delight in them.
Delightful thoughts will no longer be able to obstruct or hinder them. Delight is the seed of birth and death. The gods will thus be able to escape from desire.
In the letters on their foreheads, they will see everything. Having seen this, they will either cultivate the body or cultivate the mind.
They will be able to abandon desire, because they see the faults of desire. They will know how to escape from desire;
knowing how to escape from faults, they will see the faults of the objects of pleasure they previously enjoyed, like eating poisonous jujubes. They will see the present desires in the same way.
Why is this?
Because by enjoying the pleasures of the objects of the senses, one falls into evil destinies.
Cultivating in this way, one abandons the objects of the senses.
If in the letters on their foreheads they see the karma of the evil destinies, they will fall into the evil destiniesâ€”the hells, the realm of hungry ghosts, or the animal realm.
Having seen those karmic actions, all those karmic actions are lost;
All the karmic actions that lead to rebirth in the good destinies are born.
Because of the power of good karma.
Having seen this, those gods give rise to deep faith and create good karma, thus planting the seeds of good karma that lead to nirvana.

If there are other gods with little wisdom, whose minds delight in desire, the net of their past karma is sovereign. Having seen the written characters and signs of karma, they give rise to this thought:
'If I fall from this place later, I will be reborn among humans or among the gods.'
Having seen their place of rebirth in this way, their minds are not frightened, and they enter the river of desire for the five sense objects to bathe again.
Because of their heedlessness, they engage in heedless conduct.

Such gods have never learned or heard this before, and due to their little wisdom, they do not know desire and are unable to leave desire behind. The good Dharma will then be extinguished, and they will create other karma for rebirthâ€”the karma for hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
Why is this?
Because all good karma will be exhausted, and they will be deceived by desire and fall back into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
At that time, there was a bird named Wise Words who saw the careless gods engaging in careless conduct. Due to the good karma of the gods, it spoke a verse, saying:
If the mind is well-guided, then one will attain goodness;
If one follows unwholesomeness, then one will attain unwholesomeness.
All things are mostly due to the mind, like earth, wind, water, and fire;
According to the causes and conditions one obtains, the mind thus turns and moves.
The mind can move swiftly and can also turn swiftly;
Quickly lead them to the heavens, quickly cause them to enter the evil paths.
The mind quickly practices good, if it can guard the mind,
It can accomplish all dharmas, and cut off all karmic actions.
The master of all dharmas is called the mind;
For this reason, it is called the mind.
The mind always seeks opportunities for people, all should not trust it,
Its nature is very restless, its great power cannot be held.
In an instant, it does good, in an instant, it does evil;
Thus it creates indeterminate [karma], its actions cannot be fathomed.
The coming of the mind cannot be known, the going of the mind cannot be recognized,
First non-existent, later existent, having existed, it returns to non-existence.
The mind has no location, its accumulation cannot be obtained,
Because it has no physical body, it cannot be grasped or held.
Because of the combination of causes and conditions, thoughts arise like this moment by moment,
Just like fire is born from the combination of a gem and cow dung.
In this way, the mind of all causes and conditions such as the faculties, form, etc.,
Is not born from a single thing, but is born from the combination.
Having understood the mind in this way, know that the mind is difficult to subdue,
Let the mind follow the true Dharma, and do not delight in desires.
' Having heard these verses, the gods cultivate the body and cultivate the mind in two ways.
Having cultivated the mind, they do not delight in objects, follow the Dharma, and retreat from the Heaven of YÄma to be reborn in a superior place, not leaving the heavenly realm.

If reborn among humans, they may become a human king or a great minister, or obtain the seeds of liberation, and according to their wishes, they may attain any of the three kinds of enlightenment, or with good karma, become a wheel-turning king.

If those gods, who have such rare experiences of the signs of karma like seeing in a mirror, are not disciplined in their minds, they will fall again into the realms of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals.
Moreover, that bhiká¹£u observes this rare sign of the fruits of karma, the written words, and he then sees:

If a person diligently and wholeheartedly, with a deep mind, paints an image of the TathÄgata, or if they write the scriptures of the true Dharma with a tranquil mind of thought and faith, their mind and thoughts will be tranquil.
That person will be reborn in the heavens, and in their throat and forehead, they will see and give rise to faith.

Moreover, if a person has no correct faith, whether it is because of a royal decree, because they are sent by others, or in order to obtain wealth, for the sake of livelihood, if they write scriptures or paint Buddha images, they will also be reborn in the heavens, but when they see [the images], they will not believe and will indulge in much negligence.
They will also create the seeds of good karma and be reborn in the heavens. Although they see [the images], they will not believe, because they are separated from faith and separated from thought.
In this way, without causes, there would be no karmic fruits. In this way, everything arises from similar karmic causes and conditions.

If there are gods who are naturally inclined to indulgence and engage in indulgent conduct, experiencing the pleasures of the five sense desires of the heavens and never being content, they will again, in the mountain of increasing immeasurable desires within the Jeweled Encircling Mountains, for a long time experience the pleasures of the five sense desires and merits.

Together with the heavenly maidens, they will thus experience various kinds of play and pleasure. Later, they will leave the mountain adorned with the merits of the five sense desires and go to the third mountain of jeweled encircling mountains.

Giving rise to a joyful mind, with the sounds of the five kinds of music, they will play along the way, with all the most excellent and wonderful things perfectly accomplished. In an instant, they will fully experience pleasure, enjoying happiness according to their thoughts and various realms.
Having already experienced the pleasures of desire on the riverbank in the mountains, they will then arrive at the third mountain of jeweled encircling mountains.

In this way, the gods enjoy delightful objects and pleasures, and in this way, their joy and love increase. Because they are not liberated from attachment to those objects, they are burned by the fire of desire. They are not content with sounds, textures, tastes, forms, and smells, and are not content in the river of objects, like a minnow.

In this way, the third mountain is called the Pearl Encircling Mountain. One side is made of blue pearl jewels, the second side is made of red lotus flower jewels, the third side is made of cat's eye jewels, and the fourth side is made of white silver jewels.
When the gods see this, their minds are filled with joy, and they say to each other:
'Gods, look at these countless kinds of beautiful and wonderful lights of various kinds.
The light of these jewels pervades a million yojanas, and when it enters that light, it cannot be distinguished.
This supreme light has countless kinds of blue, yellow, red, and white colors.
The heavenly multitudes, having spoken thus, again proceeded to another forest called Dense Trees.
The heavenly multitudes and heavenly maidens, with joyful minds, with innumerable musical instruments, all delighted to see the various places.
Next, they arrived at that forest. The maturation of good karma, various adornments, thus wandering, various enjoyments, for a long time engaged in indulgent conduct, driven by desire.
At that time, the gods saw the Dense Trees Forest. In that forest, among the trees of the seven treasures, they saw two rivers:
The first was a fragrant water river, with water of superior taste and touch, filling with water according to one's thoughts.
The water of that river flowed according to one's thoughts.
On the silver banks of that river were many different kinds of birds.
That one river was called Mixed Waters;
The second river was called Wish-Fulfilling Waters.
That Mixed Waters river was of a natural essence.
The water is mixed in this way, the purest, flowing and filling up.
The various waters are free from the fault of intoxication, due to the causes and conditions of good karma.
The water has innumerable colors, therefore the river is called Mixed Waters.
The second river is called River of Wish-fulfilling Water. According to the various intentions of the gods, such water arises.
If they think of sugarcane, then the flowing of the purest white sugarcane with the best color and fragrance fills up.
If the gods think of heavenly wine, then the beautiful heavenly wine with complete color, fragrance, touch, and taste fills up and flows out.
If they think of various flowers in the mountains and fields, then such beautiful flowers with complete color, fragrance, touch, and so forth fill the river and flow out;
among the flowers are various bees that adorn them.
The name of those flowers cannot even be spoken.
In this way, the second River of Wish-fulfilling Water is filled with various flows.
In that place, among the dense forest of trees, there are such beautiful and delightful flowers.
In that place, the gods play in the two rivers, enjoying various pleasures.
Delightful sounds, textures, tastes, forms, and fragrances - they enjoy various pleasures. Because of their good karma, they drink heavenly wine together and enjoy various pleasures.
Hearing delightful sounds, various ear pleasures, various joys, they experience various pleasures in accordance with their wishes.
They are far from sorrow and grief, far from hunger and thirst, free from fear, and are never satisfied with the objects of the senses.
Like drinking salty water, their thirst increases.
There are innumerable kinds and innumerable distinctions, and they experience heavenly pleasures in innumerable ways.'
'The gods, having thus enjoyed pleasures in the forest rivers, there is a bird there called River Walker, who sees the gods being heedless and speaks a verse, saying:
'Just like this flowing water, heavenly pleasures are also like this,
Life does not abide moment by moment, but due to delusion, one is unaware.
Because of old age, sickness, and death, one is able to exhaust karma and regress,
But the heavens are not apart from this dharma, always following after desire.
Life is not permanent, and the bliss of the three realms is also like this.
The heavens are deluded by desire, and thus are unaware.
Like water droplets in the sky, they will surely fall and not remain still.
All bliss is like this, no different from raindrops.
Like wind blowing dust and dirt, they push each other and compete,
Transiting in the empty sky, the body also transits like this.
This bliss is not supreme bliss, deluded by craving and not constant,
Mixed with the poison of love, like food mixed with poison.
That which is always supreme bliss is called the place of immortality,
The place where there is no separation from love, no cold and no heat.
That place is always peaceful and secure, as the wise ones have said.
Where there is no birth and death, there is no suffering.
All pleasures that come from women are actually suffering.
Those desires are the seeds that give rise to rebirth in the hells.
Pleasure can give rise to suffering, so how can it be called pleasure?
It is suffering within suffering, and later becomes like poison.
If these beings are born, they are blown by the karmic winds of other beings.
The net of karma and delusion covers them, and they love wherever they are born.
Whether good or bad karma, it always follows them together.
It goes everywhere, like fragrance not leaving a flower.
You enjoy pleasures like this, but later you will lose them.
Just as when the day is full, the setting sun's light disappears.
The water-dwelling bird, due to the good karma of the gods, having thus spoken to all the gods who indulge in pleasures,
if the gods who indulge in pleasures and are heedless hear the water-dwelling bird speak such verses, they will say:
'This bird speaks well and has awakened us.
What the bird says, we will surely attain.
The bird speaks the truth. Because of our heedlessness, we still indulge in pleasures and are unable to give them up.
Later on, we will surely be destroyed and will experience great fear.
From now on, we should have a good mind and intention, counteract heedlessness, and abandon indulgence in pleasures.'
In this way, the gods, for a long time, with a focused good mind, abandon indulgence in pleasures and know the faults of desires.

Having contemplated with the mind, because the mind moves and the power of the mind is great, or because they have long been accustomed to desires for a long time, they again become attached to pleasures.
The gods there have immeasurable discriminations and immeasurable realms, experiencing various pleasures, with all the objects of desire fully present.
There are the sounds of various birds, and excellent gardens and forests with lotus ponds.
The peaks of the jeweled mountains are adorned with immeasurable wonderful lotus ponds, and there are immeasurable hundreds of thousands of bees making various sounds, adorning the wonderful ponds.
There are rivers there filled with food and drink.
There are hundreds of thousands of trees, with nets of branches and leaves covering the rivers, and flowers between the branches forming halls, with all kinds of things fully present.
The gods there have wonderful radiance on their own bodies, without any worries or troubles, and due to their own good karma they attain such rewards.

The gods of the lower, middle, and upper realms are all free from jealousy, mutually loving each other, with one mind and one desire, not obstructing each other. In this way, they roam and experience pleasure.
At that time, after the gods have experienced pleasure, they discuss among themselves, saying:
'As I have heard before, in this YÄma Heaven there is a lord named Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti who plays and enjoys himself. We should go there together now.'
'The gods there, five hundred yojanas away from the god-king Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, hear the singing from afar, but because it is too far, they cannot hear it clearly.
Because the sound pervades all the heavens, they cannot hear it clearly.
If the sound of the birds is like this, the sound of singing is fully endowed with merits. Although they cannot hear the singing clearly, they are extremely delighted and cannot get enough of it.
Because their minds are moved, they make up their minds that all the heavenly multitudes will go to the place where the god-king Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti plays and enjoys himself.
That forest is fully endowed with all merits.

The desire realm gods, together with the celestial maidens, adorned in various ornaments and wearing various garments, all endowed with merit, their bodies covered in heavenly garments without threads, their hands holding various musical instruments, mutually loving and cherishing each other, their minds filled with joy,
some flying in the sky, some riding on lotus flowers,
some riding on blue lotuses, those blue lotuses having the foremost fragrance, with many bees,
some riding on red lotuses, those red lotuses in shape and white color all like the lunar orb,
those gods all together with the celestial maidens, playing, singing and dancing in the sky, experiencing various pleasures of the five senses, never knowing enough.
Those gods' own minds create their own good karmic retributions, and they ride like this.

Created by their own karma, there are lower, middle, and upper [levels], and the colors are also like this, with lower, middle, and upper [levels], and the pleasures are also like this, with lower, middle, and upper [levels].
The pleasure they experience, their wisdom, and their lifespan are also like this, with lower, middling, and upper levels.
All of them are like this.
They fill the sky and head towards the Forest of Amusements, a place replete with immeasurable desires, the abode of the king of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, the hall where he resides.

As they travel in this way, before reaching the Forest of Amusements, they see a mirage-like appearance in the sky, and also see a place with the color of blue jewels, and in another place they see a yellow-white color, and in another place they see a color like fire.
The gods, having seen this in the sky, give rise to a first sense of wonder and say to each other:
'Gods, look at this wondrous thing in the sky, like various wondrously colored garments hanging in the sky.
I have never seen this before.'
Having said this to each other, the assembly of gods give rise to a sense of wonder and remain there for a short while.
Not long after, they heard another sound, the most wonderful and beautiful singing voice, and upon hearing the voice, they again felt joy and amazement.
From the ground all the way up to the sky, all the heavenly beings, together with the celestial maidens, all wished to see and go watch.
The heavenly beings in the sky all saw this;ğŸ”½The heavenly beings in the Heaven of Complete Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others also saw this from afar.
The heavenly beings in the Heaven of Complete Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others also went to the Heavenly King SuyÄma.

Heavenly King SuyÄma sat on a seat made of the seven treasures, in a cave made of the seven treasures, adorned with great blue jewels, and further adorned with the color of the most wonderful lotus flowers and the most wonderful great jewels.
Moreover, there was another most wonderful jewel banner, its light pervading a thousand yojanas, with white flames filling the sky.
Just as various wonderful clothes are worn in the sky, so are the banners.

The gods in the place of vast practice, having seen this, give rise to a rare mind and stay for a short while. In an instant, they know that the gods in the place of complete mountains and trees will also go to the place where the lord of the gods, Musulunda, resides, to the forest of amusements. They give rise to this thought:
'They are going like this, just as I am going.'
The superior gods in the place of vast practice calculate and say:
'We will now go together with the gods in the place of complete mountains and trees, all united, to the place where the lord of the gods, Musulunda, resides.'
In this way, they stay for a short while.
At that time, the gods in the place of complete mountains and trees see the assembly of gods in the place of vast practice and give rise to a rare mind, saying this:
'Now we should all go together to the pleasure grove of the king of the Thirty-three Celestials.'

Then the celestials of the place of mountains and forests and the celestials of the place of extensive activities, all the celestials united, pervading the sky with countless banners, all riding jeweled palaces on the backs of birds, with the sounds of the five musical instruments and the five sense pleasures fully endowed, heading for the pleasure grove of the SuyÄma Heaven to play in the great forest.
There are countless sense pleasures fully endowed, beyond comparison.
Going to that forest to experience the pleasures of the objects of the five desires, they are not content.
All the wealth and happiness are not content, they are not content with each other.
In this way, all experience the pleasures of desire, not knowing contentment.
The bhiká¹£u, having seen those devas, knew all the immeasurable karmic fruits and spoke a verse, saying:
Just as when rain falls, the river increases;
In the same way, because of the rain of desire, the devas' fire of desire increases.
The mina fish is born in the water, yet always suffers from thirst;
In the same way, desire increases thirst, so the devas are never satisfied.
Just as space has no boundaries, and also no end or cessation;
Desire is like this, having no boundaries, the realm of desire cannot be exhausted.
The ocean's waves and eddies are full, vaguely having the meaning of sufficiency;
Those who long for desire are ultimately never satisfied.
The devas, not yet attaining the sense objects, foolishly do not know satisfaction;
The mind always longs for happiness, having attained it, it does not know satisfaction.
Having already attained decline and distress, immeasurable, reaching to the loss of heaven,
Because of the torment of objects, one should therefore abandon desire.
Having been deceived by desire, which can destroy faith and desire,
When one encounters decline and affliction, one will be separated from it, yet the gods do not realize this.
Objects are not enough to satisfy, and the insatiable have no joy;
Thus, the insatiable, the wise are able to abandon.
Tranquility is the root of happiness, suffering arises from objects;
Therefore, one should cultivate tranquility and distance oneself from the realm of objects.
Always abandon afflictions and cultivate the unsurpassed wisdom;
From wisdom one attains liberation, bound by afflictions.
Illness, killing, bondage, and so forth, are feared due to objects;
Transmigrating in the cycle of birth and death, all arise from objects.
Whether united or separated, a hundred or a thousand times,
In every life, it is always so, only the Well-Gone One truly knows.
The pleasures of birth and death are immeasurable, and the sufferings of birth and death are immeasurable.
All arise from objects, and there are [objects] in every place of birth.
Such objects destroy the deluded mind,
But because of the blindness of delusion, one still delights in objects.
Abandoning enemies and not getting close, even hearing their name gives rise to worry,
But objects are like enemies, and because of delusion, one never abandons them.
If one is burned by objects, then one is a deluded person.
Deceived by one's own karma, because of delusion, one is unable to leave.
Just as one who fears fire still gets close to fire,
In the same way, deluded by objects, one still delights in getting close to objects.
Just as one who eats poison does not do so for one's own pleasure,
Getting close to delusion out of desire is also like this, forever without any peaceful matters.
Just as a thirsty person licking salt does not quench their thirst,
The objects of the senses are like darkness to the eyes, and one is never satisfied with desire.
The objects of the senses are not enough for the gods, deceived by the mind of desire,
Blown by the wind of karma, they arrive at the place of evil destinies.
' The bhiká¹£u thus knows the births of beings in the innumerable realms of existence, and knows them all in sequence. He has compassion for the gods and has already spoken this verse.
' Moreover, those gods gather together, all acting in the same way, and with joyful minds they go towards the abode of the king of the gods, MÅ«sa-loun-tuo, in the forest of playful enjoyment.

At that time, the gods proceed in this way, with innumerable adornments, innumerable pleasurable activities, innumerable karmic transformations, innumerable gardens, forests, ponds, and other places of enjoyment, surrounded by innumerable hundreds of thousands of celestial maidens, and proceed in this way.

There were also other gods sitting in hundreds of thousands of palaces, traveling through the sky, their light illuminating the entire sky. They sang, danced, played, and made music with the five types of instruments. Garlands adorned their bodies, and they sprinkled themselves with incense. They wore necklaces around their necks and heavenly crowns on their heads. Their clothes fluttered in the wind like clouds as they traveled. The goddesses held them in their arms, and they were filled with joy and pleasure.
There were also other gods who, upon hearing the singing and lute playing of the goddesses, became filled with love and joy.
In this way, various types of gods enjoyed various pleasures, staying in the sky above the Pleasure Grove, eagerly anticipating the pleasures to come.
All the gods in that realm headed for the abode of King Musulunda.
In general, the gods, according to their karma, played, walked, and their ornaments and sounds filled the ten directions. They all came and stayed close to the king's palace.
The entire assembly of YÄma Heaven gods, King Musulunda of YÄma Heaven is the most supreme among them.
The body is according to karma, and because of the superiority of karma, the fruit is also superior.
Such cause and effect are not dissimilar, like a seed and a sprout.
All the heavenly multitudes are close to the palace hall where King Musulunda of YÄma Heaven resides. Those gods are all inferior, only King Musulunda of YÄma Heaven is supreme among them.
Among all the gods, the desires of the heavenly king are superior, and he is fully endowed with them.
The pleasures without analogy, I will speak a little.
There are seven-jeweled birds on the trees in the forest, surrounding everywhere.
Their beaks hold the heart of the tree, and their bodies are unsupported in the sky.
Moreover, in another place there are rare bells, their sound is beautiful and wonderful. If the gods hear it, they all come towards it.
In this way, because of the joy of the discriminating mind, they roam in that forest.
There are also seven-jeweled birds with mixed-colored wings, flying around the forest outside, holding garlands in their beaks.
There are also many rare peacocks, all with lotus ponds on their backs.
In those ponds are many kinds of birds, with hundreds of thousands of bees in the lotus flowers in the pond water, making buzzing sounds.
The pond is called Clear Water.
The lotus leaves are of various colors, with some flower leaves made of vaiá¸Å«rya and some flower leaves made of the seven treasures.
Some lotus flowers have a fragrance of five yojanas.
In this way, the backs of those birds, the peacocks, are dignified and marvelous, singing, playing, and frolicking, in harmony with the pond birds.
The backs of those peacocks are also extremely rare.
There are also many great rare birds, with peacocks holding garlands, meaning there are large lotus flowers on their backs.
The king sits on the lotus platform, surrounded by a hundred celestial maidens, enjoying pleasures with various amusements, beautiful songs, and delightful music.
Moreover, there are many rare and extraordinary birds, peacocks holding garlands.
The heavenly beings who experience pleasure are transformed by their own karma. On the head of each peacock, there grows a wish-fulfilling tree.
There are various flowers, abundant and plentiful. On the trees, there are many birds with wings of the seven treasures.
When the heavenly beings climb the trees, they drink heavenly wine with the celestial maidens, sing and dance, play and enjoy pleasures.
Again, there are many rare and extraordinary birds, peacocks holding garlands.
In the dense feathers of each peacock, many heavenly beings sit with the celestial maidens, enjoying pleasures, loving each other, singing and dancing, and experiencing heavenly bliss.
The heavenly beings see such rare and extraordinary things as peacocks holding garlands, and give rise to a sense of wonder.
They will also see a second marvel, namely, the wonderful lotus pond with garlands.

That lotus pond has twenty thousand petals, free from muddy turbidity, with golden and silver sands, and the water of the eight virtues fills the pond, with geese, ducks, and mandarin ducks in abundance.
Due to the good karma of the gods, the geese speak a verse, saying:
'For a long time, one experiences this pleasure, but this pleasure is not a permanent dharma.
All are impermanent, yet the gods do not realize it.
This pleasure is for now, but it will definitely be cut off.
Deceived by the mind of desire, one does not realize the loss and destruction.
This pleasure is mixed with suffering and pleasure, and one does not realize it because it is concealed;
Just like a poisonous snake cannot be seen in a garland of lotus flowers.
Just like poisoned rice, the eater is killed;
This pleasure is all like that, and one will definitely fall into hell.'ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Like a snare made of sinews, the eyes see it as very lovely;
The snare of objects is like this, what seems good is actually very bad.
Like the fruit of the kimpaka tree, initially sweet and delicious,
Later it can kill, worldly pleasures are also like this.
Like a flying insect sees a lamp, its mind is very fond of it,
Entering it, it is then burned, this pleasure is also like this.
Foolish ordinary beings do not know, play and pleasure are like a lamp,
Desiring pleasure is like touching fire, in the end one does not obtain pleasure.
Like a deer suffering from thirst, following after a mirage, running,
In the end it does not quench its thirst, this pleasure is also like this.
The past and present do not know contentment, the future is also like this,
All heavenly realms, thus one should abandon them.
Tranquil pleasure is the root of pleasure, this is what the wise say,
Those without a mind in the faculty of pleasure will always experience suffering.
Brahma is truly the most supreme, patience is the most tranquil,
One wisdom illuminates the world, one compassion produces supreme bliss.
Not harming others is the most auspicious, right view is the foremost good,
Upright mind is the most beneficial, abandoning evil karma is the same.
If one approaches the elders, always respecting the Dharma,
Making offerings to the teachers and elders, believing in karma is good.
Always making offerings to the Three Jewels, with a pure mind and no defilements,
And making offerings to one's parents, this is the path to the city of nirvana.
The Buddha says that among all dharmas, leaving the household life is the foremost,
The practice of pure conduct is supreme among practices, and can attain all bliss.
The Buddha says that among all kinds of giving, giving the Dharma is the most excellent;
Among efforts, meditation is the foremost, and can reach nirvana.
Among giving, morality, and wisdom, wisdom is the best.
Wisdom can reach nirvana, while giving and morality only lead to happiness.
Seeing with the eyes is not the best, seeing with wisdom is superior.
The Buddha taught the eightfold path, which is the most peaceful of all paths.
Among the truths, the four noble truths are supreme, as taught by the Tathagata.
Among the five kinds of powers, the power of wisdom is the best.
It is said that above, below, and in the eight directions, there is no one superior,
Only the Tathagata is supreme, because he can show the true Dharma.
Among all assemblies, the noble assembly is the most peaceful,
Relying on the three jewels as a field of merit can give rise to happiness.
Equally making offerings to parents, and thirdly to the preceptor,
